attributes.comment:
I am very concerned with the proposed increase in fees for U.S. Citizenship and
Immigration Services), docket number (USCIS-2006-0044). This blanket increase in
fees will add further barriers to Americans trying to adopt orphans from other
countries, without any guarantee of better service delivery or accountability.

The first argument for this increase in fees noted in the Federal Register is to
increase service delivery. As a recent client at USCIS I was disappointed by the
3 hour wait in line to get fingerprints (and subsequent re-do of the prints a
month later because the quality was poor), however, unless this fee increase
will guarantee certain specifically outlined deliverables, I do not see a
service delivery benefit to clients. "Increase service delivery" is a very vague
and bureaucratic goal if there is not a specific action plan for the use of the
funds that guarantees specific service delivery goals. If certain service
delivery benchmarks were guaranteed and justified (ie. the clients of USCIS
agree that they want specific levels of service and are willing to pay for
them), then the proposed increase could be worthwhile. However, I did not see
any such mention of specific goals that respond to client expectations with the
regulation. It is so sickening to me that the government might allow this
increase in fees without accountability for the funds that would add value to
the clients it aims to serve.

I also wanted to comment the statement made in the Federal Register: "The rule
would permit U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services to devote certain
revenues to broader investments in a new technology and business process
platform to improve substantially its capabilities and service levels." Again,
what accountability is there that this will produce better service levels? The
regulation did not outline the action steps that would guarantee better service
delivery.

A 66% increase in fees for no *guarantee* for increased service delivery is
unacceptable. I do not support this regulation and hope that my fellow Americans
who are making decisions about this policy will not either.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Sarah Lenssen
